CLOSING Quick Write: What Is Perspective? In eighth grade, you will be reading and writing about texts, videos, and pictures.
Our next routine is called a Quick Write, which is just that—quick. Don’t worry too much about getting all your words exactly right during a Quick Write. It is more important that you get your ideas down.
First, write a brief response to the following question:
What do you already know about perspective?
OPEN NOTEBOOK
Share your response with the class.

Episode 1: It Depends on How You Look at It, Lesson 1

Closing Task 4: Quick Write: What Is Perspective? Duration: 5–10 min Explain to students that every lesson ends with a Closing that will recap, focus, connect, or extend the ideas and skills of the lesson. Sometimes this time will be to reflect while other times it will prepare students for homework. This is a good opportunity to demonstrate for students how to use the dictionary to help understand the word perspective. Allow students to share their responses. Begin a chart titled “Perspective.” Do a quick thumbs-up, thumbs-down check to ensure that students understand the meaning of perspective. They will be coming back to this word and its importance many times throughout the unit and the year. Differentiation If time permits, close the activity by doing an in-class reading of the first paragraph of the Foreword to Red Scarf Girl written by David Henry Hwang. Hwang was approximately nine years old during the events described in Ji-li’s memoir. He grew up in America and his sense of the revolution in China was partly shaped by communication from a distant uncle back in China. This uncle would communicate the status of things through his posture in photographs. Hwang closes the Foreword by reflecting on the power of Ji-li’s memoir in helping him understand the perspective of his uncle and how he must have felt lying down for a photo to be snapped, thinking of his relatives in America. Based on the Forward’s first paragraph only, ask students to compare and contrast how Hwang might have viewed the photograph as a boy to how he viewed it as an adult. Note how a single person may change perspective over time. Invite students to consider how reading Ji-li’s memoir, yet another perspective, may play a further role in Hwang’s view of his uncle, of the events in China, and of the struggles that inevitably shape all of us. Emerging P1.8.6
Explain to Emerging ELLs that when you contrast you are looking for things that are different. When you compare you are looking for things that are the “same or similar.” Then use a mathematical formula to demonstrate the meaning: Different + viewpoint = contrast perspective Similar + viewpoint = comparable perspective Expanding P1.8.6
The amplification in the Emerging level also applies for this level. Bridging P1.8.6
The amplification in the Emerging level also applies for this level. Allow for several minutes at the end of class to explain the homework assignment.
Now that you’re starting eighth grade, you may find that your point of view is changing as you get older and learn more about the world. This is a good time to think about perspectives!
Each of us has a perspective, or point of view. Knowing your own and others’ perspectives gives you options to understand or change how you live in the world and how others see you.
The Guiding Questions are the “big questions” you will be thinking about in each unit. For Unit 1, the following are your Guiding Questions.
How can readers understand the perspective of a writer?
How do competing perspectives cause conflict?
Now spend a few minutes reviewing and discussing the Unit Accomplishments.

You will be spending the whole year working closely with the other students in this class. You will be reading and talking about books, reading one another’s work and giving feedback, watching videos and discussing what you like and dislike.
Take a few minutes to talk with one other person.
Find someone in the room that you have never talked with before (or not very much).
Take a couple of minutes to think of an unusual quality, trait, or skill you have, and write about it. Then share your thoughts with your partner in the following way.
The first speaker talks for 3 minutes.
Then the second says back what the first said.
Then the first speaker says back what the second says.
Then together write a quick response to the following questions.
What was the same about your responses?

In the course of this introductory unit, you will get a chance to work with all of your classmates. This will help you find new friends and will also help you get to know students that you work well with.

Now that you have experienced Whole Group Discussions and reviewed the big projects you will accomplish in this unit, it is time to set some rules with your class to help make your work together respectful and productive.
First, read the Student Discussion Guidelines.

Then take a few minutes to think about some rules you would like the class to have that would make you feel comfortable speaking in a large group. Everybody has to share so you should think about what would make this easier for you.
Write a quick response to the following question.
What should our rules be for having respectful conversations?
Share one of your rules for respectful conversations. Listen as others are sharing. Try not to repeat what others have said.
In eighth grade, you will be reading and writing about texts, videos, and pictures.

Our next routine is called a Quick Write, which is just that—quick. Don’t worry too much about getting all your words exactly right during a Quick Write. It is more important that you get your ideas down.
First, write a brief response to the following question:
What do you already know about perspective?
Share your response with the class.
What Kind of Reader Are You?

Complete the three forms (A Reader’s Introduction, Reading Likes and Dislikes, Reading/Writing Autobiography) to offer yourself, your teacher, and your classmates an accurate picture of you as a reader.

Select two or three objects you find interesting. Take photographs of each object from several different angles, so that the viewer will see it from several different perspectives. Submit your favorite series of photos to your teacher.
Write a brief response to the following questions.
How does perspective, or point of view, influence the way you see something?
Why is perspective important? Name a situation in which perspective plays an important role.
Now that you’re starting eighth grade, you may find that your point of view is changing as you get older and learn more about the world. This is a good time to think about perspectives!

You will be spending the whole year working closely with the other students in this class. You will be reading and talking about books, reading one another’s work and giving feedback, watching videos and discussing what you like and dislike.

Now that you have experienced Whole Group Discussions and reviewed the big projects you will accomplish in this unit, it is time to set some rules with your class to help make your work together respectful and productive.
In eighth grade, you will be reading and writing about texts, videos, and pictures.
What Kind of Reader Are You?

Complete the three forms (A Reader’s Introduction, Reading Likes and Dislikes, Reading/Writing Autobiography) to offer yourself, your teacher, and your classmates an accurate picture of you as a reader.
